properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. Heavy snowfall begins just after midnight and continues into Wednesday morning. Snow is expected to move into the region overnight and persist for much of the day on Wednesday. The snow may fall heavily at times, particularly overnight and early Wednesday morning. Total snowfall accumulations near 15 centimetres are expected. A few locations may receive in excess of 20 centimetres by Wednesday evening due to lake effect snow bands from lake Superior Wednesday afternoon into the evening. Snow squall warnings may be issued after the main snowfall event due to snow bands that will likely become isolated by Wednesday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-30T12:44:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-29T20:44:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3610434555.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. 50 mm of rain for Metro Vancouver through Wednesday. A Pacific frontal system will produce heavy rain for Metro Vancouver beginning early this evening. Rainfall amounts in excess of 50 mm can be expected through Wednesday. The rain will ease to a few showers by Thursday morning. The heavy rainfall will drag freezing levels down to 200 metres tonight. Localized snowfall accumulation of 2 to 5 cm is expected over higher terrain tonight. Freezing levels will rise Wednesday morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Be prepared for possible winter conditions at higher elevations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-30T15:33:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-29T23:33:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1388766107.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 15 to 20 cm of snow will fall over the Sea to Sky Highway tonight and Wednesday as a moisture-laden frontal wave moves across southern B.C. The snow will be wet and significant accumulation isn't expected until early Wednesday morning. The likeliest snowfall accumulation will be over sections that are above 200 metres. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-30T05:09:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-29T13:09:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0881817773.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. An intense winter storm centred near Southampton Island continues to support strong northwest winds and and blizzard conditions to parts of the Kivalliq coastline. The strong winds supporting the blizzard will begin to abate tonight. Conditions will improve this evening Rankin Inlet and Whale Cove, followed by Chesterfield Inlet overnight, although lingering periods of blowing snow may persist into Wednesday. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-30T10:59:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-29T20:40:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2593432417.2020
Area: Rankin Region including Whale Cove, Chesterfield Inlet

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong winds with gusts to 90 km/h are creating near zero visibilities in blowing snow. This evening the winds are expected to weaken and therefore the visibility in blowing snow will improve. However the improvement will be short lived. By Wednesday morning the winds are once again expected to strengthen with wind gusts approaching 90 km/h. These strong winds will create blizzard conditions again Wednesday morning. The strong winds and blizzard conditions will subside Wednesday night. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-30T11:08:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-29T19:08:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0489595736.2020
Area: Grise Fiord
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds with gusts of 100 km/h or more will continue this morning. Winds will gradually diminish by afternoon. Poor visibility in blowing snow will also occur at times. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Southeast winds of 90 km/h will continue tonight over the exposed coastal sections of North Vancouver Island and Central Coast - coastal sections as a frontal system has stalled near the Central Coast. Winds will ease Wednesday morning as the system weakens. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall: up to 15 cm except possibly near 30 cm over the Highlands. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: tonight and Wednesday morning. Remarks: Flurries heavy at times will develop this evening possibly producing rapid snowfall accumulation. Areas of snow squall activity are possible overnight and Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds strengthen. These winds will produce blowing snow which will reduce visibility. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-30T11:58:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-29T19:58:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2280641996.2020
